de.cocolab.reuse
Class TestDataGenerator

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.util.Random
        |
        +--de.cocolab.reuse.TestDataGenerator
public class TestDataGenerator
extends java.util.Random

Test data generation.

Extends the standard Random class to generate test data for Cocktail applications (or to test the Cocktail reuse classes).

Version:
$Id: $
See Also:

Constructor Detail

TestDataGenerator

public TestDataGenerator()
Creates a new random number generator. Its seed is initialized to a value based on the current time.

Creates a new random number generator using a specified long seed.

Parameters:
seed - the initial seed.
See Also:
Random.setSeed(long)
Method Detail

nextIdentifier

public java.lang.String nextIdentifier(int minLength,
                                       int maxLength)
Generate a String which looks like an identifier according to common rules.

The result will begin with a letter and continue with letters or digits.

Parameters:
minLength - No identifier shorter than minLength will be generated. minLength must be >= 1.
maxLength - No identifier longer than maxLength will be generated. maxLength must be >= minLength.
Returns:
A string containing only letters and digits, beginning with a letter, of length between minLength and inclusive.

nextIntD

public int nextIntD()

Generate a random integer with roughly equal probability that it has any particular number of digits.

Random.nextInt() generates a truly random number, which means you very rarely get a single digit result for example. Using nextIntD gives a roughly 1/10 chance that the result will be one digit (or two digits ...). This is much more useful for testing things like print routines.

nextInt

public int nextInt(int n)
Returns a pseudorandom, uniformly distributed int value between 0 (inclusive) and the specified value (exclusive), drawn from this random number generator's sequence.

After JDK 1.2 this method is no longer required, as it already exists in exactly this form in java.util.Random. It is here so that Cocktail works correctly before JDK 1.2. It merely overrides the method from Random with an identical implementation.

Overrides:
nextInt in class java.util.Random
Returns:
a pseudorandom, uniformly distributed int value between 0 (inclusive) and n (exclusive).
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - n is not positive.
Since:
JDK1.2
